course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Buddhism: Origin and Growth
course.description: An examination of the historical, religious and philosophical foundation of the Buddhist tradition in India and exploration of the history of Buddhism as a world religion with an emphasis on the basic doctrines and philosophy of Buddhism.

reviews.author: wlyauab
reviews.title: Basic knowledge of Buddhism
reviews.comment_content: It covers about basically the history of Buddhism at first and different factions of the idea of Buddhism in India.
reviews.comment_teaching: Apart from the required content, the professor will use some daily life examples or personal experience to help us understand the abstract ideas.
reviews.comment_workload: Have a few readings every week, not mandatory. Readings can help you understand the more abstract idea of Buddhism. Just need to understand the content and memorise some keywords before the quizzes, such as the name of some readings and the advocators of the ideas. The quizzes will be held in form of MC and some short questions. Sometimes, he will ask us a question and let us form groups to answer the questions in paper. There are no limit for the words of the in-class essay, depending on the how much time he gives you during class time.

reviews.author: PP
reviews.title: Interesting Buddhism Course
reviews.comment_content: The content is good for basic knowledge of Buddhism. However, if you already have Buddhism knowledge, you should not take this course so that it won't confuse you. If you are a Buddhist with strong and clear mindset, you may take this course to learn different types of Buddhism around the world.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor will cover not only the contents in the slides as well as talk about other experiences that he's encountered before.

reviews.author: LuQ
reviews.title: Great course with very low workload, not bad grading either
reviews.comment_teaching: If english is not your native language, you will probably get lost easily when the prof speaks. It's just paragraph after paragraph after paragraph, I've never had a prof that was stuck in 1 slide for 20 or so minutes, can happen at times, and he gets off topic quite a lot if someone asks questions. A number of side topics is talked about in class. But otherwise, still interesting as you can tell his passion towards Buddhism.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good actually.
There is an in-class essay after group discussion. As well as several in-class group exercise/discussion.
Surprisingly, there's no midterm or final, just 3 quizzes, which includes MCs, short and long question. Though there is attendance needed.

The 1st quiz had me worried as it was the first time they've had this course. but got well-above the mean. 2nd quiz was during midterm season, sadly BSed through it, but still got a hefty amount of marks, and got a bit above mean. We never got our 3rd quiz back. But I got a B+ in the end, I guess that's the benefit if you take a class full of exchange students :P
reviews.comment_workload:
Very very light workload. No homework at all. There are readings, but half the time, you just need to take a look at the PPT to get a summary. Besides, only the concept of what's said in the book is talked about, not the readings itself, no strong evaluation of the materials is needed.
A lot of the questions are about listing things, definitions, explanation of concepts and such, things that are easily found in the PPTs.

reviews.author: HugoSch
reviews.comment_content: Very interesting. There is a powerpoint and the video of the course is available afterwards. It is structured. The teacher suggests some videos that can help understanding the lesson afterwards.
reviews.comment_teaching: Passionnated and lively teacher. The way he speaks is understandable, and it is easy to follow him. The content of each course is quite reasonable.
reviews.comment_grading: There are 3 quizzes during the semester. The participation in class is marked too, and there are points for discussions with other students.
reviews.comment_workload: There are some readings available on Canvas in english and Chinese, but not mandatory to prepare the course.
